body: From https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_pull_requests/9716/config=dbg,language=objc,platform=macos/console we need to install Cocoapods 1.0.0 on our Jenkins slave.
Test this please
test this please

Jorge, could you clarify the local pods that we need to specify in our Podfile to test?

I'm assuming that our Podfile will need a few lines like the following: 

```
    pod 'gRPC', :path => 'local/grpc'
    pod 'gRPC-Core', :path => 'local/grpc'
    pod 'gRPC-RxLibrary', :path => 'local/grpc'
```

What else should we be doing - specifically for BoringSSL and Protobuf? I notice that when I build with the above lines in my Podfile and your grpc branch, I get this build error:

```
    'openssl/asn1.h' file not found
```

For Protobuf, you need to use version `3.0.0-beta-3.1`, which @TeBoring just gifted us with :)

For BoringSSL, you need the podspec changes in this PR, so you need to tell your `Podfile` to use the local podspec (but with remote sources). You achieve that by using the `:podspec` symbol, [as in here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/6849/files#diff-96f8370f7047d7cacf63c7110d95e9f3R12).
And if your test includes generated files, those need to depend on `gRPC-ProtoRPC`.

@jcanizales Jorge, thanks for your PR. I've just tried to incorporate it in my project to get gRPC up and running, here's my 'Podfile' I used: ``` target 'whatever' do platform :ios, '9.0' use_frameworks! fix_repo = 'https://github.com/jcanizales/grpc.git' fix_branch = 'support-dynamic-frameworks' pod 'Protobuf' pod 'BoringSSL', :podspec => "https://github.com/jcanizales/grpc/raw/#{fix_branch}/src/objective-c/BoringSSL.podspec" pod 'gRPC', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}" pod 'gRPC-Core', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}" pod 'gRPC-RxLibrary', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}" pod 'gRPC-ProtoRPC', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}" end ``` Unfortunately, I've got the following errors:

Hi Roman!

Because the `gRPC-Core` pod uses submodules, when you use `:git` `:branch` for it in your `Podfile` you need to add a third parameter: `:submodules => true`. I.e.:

``` ruby
target 'whatever' do
  platform :ios, '9.0'
  use_frameworks!

  fix_repo = 'https://github.com/jcanizales/grpc.git'
  fix_branch = 'support-dynamic-frameworks'

  pod 'Protobuf'
  pod 'BoringSSL', :podspec => "https://github.com/jcanizales/grpc/raw/#{fix_branch}/src/objective-c/BoringSSL.podspec"

  pod 'gRPC', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}"
  pod 'gRPC-Core', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}", :submodules => true
  pod 'gRPC-RxLibrary', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}"
  pod 'gRPC-ProtoRPC', :git => "#{fix_repo}", :branch => "#{fix_branch}"
end
```

That should fix your problem, as nanopb's sources are brought in as a submodule.

Also, nice trick pointing `:podspec` to a URL; I didn't know one could do that!
@jcanizales that's strange because looking at https://github.com/jcanizales/grpc/blob/support-dynamic-frameworks/gRPC-Core.podspec one can see that `:submodules => true` is actually there...

Yeah, I think the explanation is that, after Cocoapods clones the repo you specified in your Podfile, it uses the podspec in it but ignores the `source` attribute (because it's going to use the files in the repo it just cloned). So then it never gets to init the submodules, if it didn't upon cloning the repo. But let me know if the change I suggested doesn't work for you, because I recall it happened to me too at some point and I solved it that way.

@jcanizales your solution works perfectly. But I've run into other problem now related to my own generated ptorobuf and gRPC files. Maybe you can help me with that? Here's my .podspec file: ``` Pod::Spec.new do |s| s.name = 'david' s.version = '0.1.0' s.summary = 'API for the project "David"' s.homepage = 'https://github.com/mesmerizingr/david' s.authors = { 'Roman Homoliako' => 'rhomoliako@gmail.com' } s.source = { :git => 'https://github.com/mesmerizingr/david.git', :tag => s.version } s.ios.deployment_target = '9.0' objc_rpc_out_dir = 'objc' s.prepare_command = <<-CMD mkdir -p #{objc_rpc_out_dir} protoc --objc_out #{objc_rpc_out_dir} --objcgrpc_out #{objc_rpc_out_dir} rpc/v0/*.proto CMD s.subspec "Messages" do |ms| ms.source_files = "#{objc_rpc_out_dir}/**/*.pbobjc.{h,m}" ms.header_mappings_dir = "#{objc_rpc_out_dir}" ms.requires_arc = false ms.dependency "Protobuf", "~> 3.0.0-alpha-4" ms.pod_target_xcconfig = { 'GCC_PREPROCESSOR_DEFINITIONS' => '$(inherited) GPB_USE_PROTOBUF_FRAMEWORK_IMPORTS=1', } end s.subspec "Services" do |ss| ss.source_files = "#{objc_rpc_out_dir}/**/*.pbrpc.{h,m}" ss.header_mappings_dir = "#{objc_rpc_out_dir}" ss.requires_arc = true ss.dependency "gRPC", "~> 0.12" ss.dependency "#{s.name}/Messages" end end ``` After the `pod install` I have all my generated files stored inside `Pods/david/objc/rpc/v0/*`. But by building my project I get the following errors: What am I doing wrong?

@jcanizales Ok, I identified my problem. It was related to invocation peculiarities of `protoc` compiler that I've been using. Also, I got pre-processor compilation problem that hinted me that I had been using `protoc` compiler with incompatible version (the newest that resolves include errors is `3.0.0-beta-3.1` and mine was `3.0.0-beta-3`). But in the end I (again) got include problems but now they're coming from generated files: I tried to change it to `#import `, `#import ` and even `#import ` but that didn't help. My idea is that changes in the PR should also take into account `protoc` generated gRPC code.

In your protos podspec, apart from setting the new Protobuf preprocessor macro, you have to change the dependency in your Services subspec from 'gRPC' to 'gRPC-ProtoRPC'.
Sorry for not having made that clear!

@jcanizales now it works. It was quite a long run 😅 But I think I will wait till 14 release when CocoaPods ~> 1.0.0 support stabilizes. Hope it would be stable by that time. All that fuzzy hacks targeting work-in-progress branches don't suite me.
Glad it works for you! This PR and pointing our Protobuf dependency to beta-3.1 are the only things remaining to release v14.
@jcanizales may I ask you why did you separate gRPC onto different parts? Was it necessary to make gRPC be packaged as a dynamic framework?
test this please

> Was it necessary to make gRPC be packaged as a dynamic framework?

That's correct. Cocoapods will only create one framework per podspec (not per subspec). So keeping the four libraries as subspecs of one podspec would have meant users switching to dynamic frameworks needing to rewrite their imports (and we try very hard not to break existing code since we went beta).

It would have also meant complicating the podspec even more (assuming it was actually possible to achieve in one podspec), while the separation simplified them all.

One downside of the separation is that people have to change s/gRPC/gRPC-ProtoRPC/ in their proto-generating podspecs. But we already have to ask them to modify the podspec to add the new Protobuf macro, so it's something we had to do anyway. Another downside is a bit more of work when submitting the podspecs to Cocoapods' trunk. Hopefully, we'll automate that submission soon so we don't have to care about that.

Yep, you could have made the same changes 'Protobuf' authors did modifying imports but it would feel like "code smell", you know. More cleaner (but somewhere clunky) way was to add few hacks here and there in .podspec files and that's what you did.

@mesmerizingr The problem solved in the protobuf side was slightly different. There, the need was:
- `#import "google/protobuf/Any.pbobjc.h"` for build systems like Blaze that don't move headers around.
- `#import <Protobuf/Any.pbobjc.h>` or `#import <Protobuf/google/protobuf/Any.pbobjc.h>` for Cocoapods using dynamic frameworks.
- For Cocoapods using static libraries, any of the three options above could be made to work. This was important because it meant all Cocoapods users could use the same type of imports, independently of whether they wanted dynamic frameworks. So we could define the preprocessor macro in Protobuf.podspec and have it defined for all Cocoapods users (at least we were counting on that :) ).

In gRPC we already had the headers under directories matching the library names (e.g. `src/objective-c/GRPCClient/GRPCCall.h`), which worked alright for both Blaze and Cocoapods-static-libraries. If we kept only one podspec, the imports when using dynamic frameworks would need to be like `<gRPC/...>` for all four libraries. But podspecs can't tell whether dynamic frameworks are going to be used or not, because that's specified in the app's `Podfile`. So the sanest thing was just to split.
Friendly ping @makdharma and @timburks for reviewing.
So currently, if I want to fix my 'openssl/mem.h file not found' error, which steps should I follow?
LGTM. @timburks please take a look.

@rohinb, given that this is already reviewed by both Tim and Makarand, I think the easiest is to wait for it to be merged and the 0.14 pod pushed to Cocoapods. If you want to try it _right now_ you can follow the steps @mesmerizingr did above.
Just wondering, when would this push happen?

I've reviewed this and consider it ready to submit. We've verified the
change for user-generated protocol buffer descriptions and also tested with
Google protobuf definitions from http://github.com/googleapis/googleapis.
The generated code for these has a hierarchical file structure that
currently does _not_ compile in Xcode (even with this change) but we plan
to address that in another PR.
